functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.

msg.content: Where are the best-selling female rappers from?
Where are the best-selling female rappers from?

<document>
<title>Nicki Minaj</title>
<fragment>
	* Ramirez, Erika (March 31, 2014). "Ladies First: 31 Female Rappers Who Changed Hip-Hop". *Billboard*. Retrieved March 30, 2022. Many female rhymers, from Queen Latifah to Nicki Minaj, have destroyed the proverbial glass ceiling to become legends in their own right. In celebration of women's history month, we're spotlighting 31 of the greatest female rappers of all time.
	* Staples, Brent (July 7, 2012). "Nicki Minaj Crashes Hip-Hop's Boys Club". *The New York Times*. ISSN 0362-4331. Retrieved March 30, 2022. Two albums later ... [Minaj] is already being hailed, with some justification, as the most influential female rapper of all time.
	* "Saweetie, City Girls and the Female Rapper Renaissance". *The New York Times*. November 29, 2020. ISSN 0362-4331. Retrieved March 30, 2022. Now, finally, things appear to be evolving in a more progressive direction. Nicki Minaj has been one of the most influential rappers of the last decade.

</fragment>
<fragment>

In 2012, Jon Caramanica of *The New York Times* called Minaj "the most influential female rapper of all time", and in 2015 Vanessa Grigoriadis from its magazine called her "the world's biggest female rap superstar".[308][387] In *Evening Standard*, Jochan Embley called her one of the most influential rap artists of all time, saying that "Everything she does is bold, fearless and distinct – whether that be her eye-popping stage attire or her expertly delivered lyrics, which stare gender and race dead in the eye."[418] Zoe Johnson from *XXL* called her "one of the most versatile MCs" and that she has "made millions off upbeat pop hits and traditional hip-hop sounds that cater to both her femininity and her assertive side".[323]


</fragment>
<fragment>

For *NPR Music*, Sowmya Krishnamurthy noted that Minaj has portrayed "the quirky, life-size Barbie, glamorous vixen and girl-next-door", arguing that she "changed the landscape for artists in hip-hop for the past decade" with said alter egos.[419] In 2017, Patrik Sandberg of *Dazed* argued that Minaj has "surpassed every other female hip hop artist to become the most successful in history" in 2017.[420] In 2020, Nick Soulsby of PopMatters called her the "best female rapper and the best rapper of the past ten years – no gender preposition required."[421] *Glamour* included Minaj in their list of 104 women who defined 2010s pop culture.[422]




</fragment>
<fragment>
	* Caramanica, Jon (March 30, 2012). "A Singular Influence". *The New York Times*. ISSN 0362-4331. Retrieved March 30, 2022. This hard and complex work has paid off: when she releases her second album, 'Pink Friday: Roman Reloaded', this week, it will be as the most influential female rapper of all time.
	* Embley, Jochan (June 16, 2020). "From Nas to Drake, the most influential hip hop artists of all time". *Evening Standard*. Retrieved March 30, 2022. For many, it was an searing introduction to [Minaj] who would dominate pop music, fashion and social politics for much of this decade, repeatedly breaking down barriers for female artists in the scene.
	* Harrington, Jim (August 6, 2020). "Top 10 female rappers of all time: Did your favorite make our list?". *The Mercury News*. Retrieved March 30, 2022. [Minaj] has breathtaking talent and is able to accomplish things on the microphone that are simply spellbinding.

</fragment>
<fragment>

Minaj has twenty-one top 10 singles on the chart, the most for any female rapper, with six of those being solo songs.[464][465] In 2017, Minaj broke the record for most Hot 100 entries by any female artist, surpassing Aretha Franklin, and in 2018, she became the first female artist to accumulate 100 entries on the Hot 100. She held the mentioned record for most Hot 100 entries by a female artist until it was broken in December 2020 by singer-songwriter Taylor Swift.[466][467][468][469] She is the female artist with the second-most Hot 100 entries, behind Swift.[470][471] In 2019, *Billboard* Women in Music awarded her with the Game Changer Award.[472][473]


</fragment>
<fragment>
since "Fancy" by Australian rapper Iggy Azalea featuring English singer Charli XCX did it in 2014.[209] It marked the first time that a song by two female rappers reached the top, for which Guinness World Records later gave them an award.[210][211] A month later, she released a collaboration with 6ix9ine called "Trollz", which debuted at number one in the U.S. becoming her second number one single.[212] This made her the first female rapper to debut at number one on the *Billboard* Hot 100 since Lauryn Hill did so in 1998 with "Doo Wop (That Thing)".[213]


</fragment>
</document>

msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Cardi B</title>
<fragment>

Cardi B is the female rapper with the most *Billboard* Hot 100 number one singles (5)[169] and the one with the most total weeks on the top position (16).[105][169] "I Like It" became the first song led by a female rapper to surpass a billion streams on Spotify, making her the first woman in hip hop with multiple billion-streamers on the service, with a total of three so far.[343][344] With the singles "Taki Taki" and "WAP" she became the only female rapper to top the global Spotify chart multiple times.[154] Since August 2020, "WAP" holds the record of the biggest first-week streams for a song in the United States.[154] *Invasion of Privacy* was the top female rap album of the 2010s, according to the *Billboard* 200 decade-end chart.[345] It became the longest-charting album by a female rapper on the *Billboard* 200,[346] and the most-streamed female rap album on Spotify.[347]


</fragment>
<fragment>
Recognized by *Forbes* as one of the most influential female rappers of all time, Cardi B holds various records among women in hip hop; she is the female rapper with the most number-one singles (five) on the *Billboard* Hot 100, the only to achieve multiple solo number ones and the only to earn number ones in two decades (2010s and 2020s) on the chart. She is also the female rapper with the most diamond-certified songs (three) by the RIAA, the highest-certified female rapper of all time on their Top Artists (Digital Singles) ranking, and has 100 million certified units (album and songs) sold in the US alone. Additionally, she is the female rapper with the most songs with a billion streams on Spotify—where she also has the most-streamed female rap album. She was the first lead artist to top the *Billboard* Global 200. Her accolades include a Grammy Award, eight *Billboard* Music Awards, six Guinness World Records, six American Music Awards, 14 BET Hip Hop Awards, and two ASCAP Songwriter of the Year awards. 
</fragment>
<fragment>
333. **^** Michael Saponara (July 11, 2019). "Cardi B Urges Fans to Support Female MCs Who Don't Rap About Sex". *Billboard*.
334. **^** Eli Countryman (August 7, 2020). "Cardi B Is Over Being Pitted Against Other Female Artists: 'Why Does It Even Have to Be Like That?'". *Variety*.
335. **^** "10 record-breaking celebrity achievements from 2018". *Guinness World Records*. December 21, 2018. Retrieved May 1, 2022.
336. **^** "Most RIAA Diamond singles for a female artist". *Guinness World Records*. February 6, 2022. Retrieved May 1, 2022.
337. **^** "Most US No.1 singles by a female rapper". *Guinness World Records*. September 29, 2018. Retrieved May 1, 2022.
338. **^** "First solo female artist to win Best Rap Album at the Grammy Awards". *Guinness World Records*. February 10, 2019. Retrieved May 1, 2022.
339. **^** "Most streamed album on Apple Music in one week by a female artist". *Guinness World Records*. April 13, 2018. Retrieved May 1, 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>
Cardi is the female rapper with the most Diamond-certified songs by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) (3): "Bodak Yellow", which made her the first female rapper to have a song certified Diamond; "Girls Like You", which made her the only female rapper to achieve multiple Diamond-certified songs; and "I Like It", a tie for the most among women artists.[348][114][349][350] Cardi B has topped twice *Pitchfork*'s annual list of best songs of the year (2017 and 2020).[77][351] *Billboard* staff and *Rolling Stone* ranked her debut album number 13 and 34 on their critics' lists of the best albums of the 2010s respectively, both the highest rank for a female rapper for the decade.[352][353] Cardi B has become the highest-certified female rapper of all time on the RIAA's Top Artists (Digital Singles) ranking, with 54 million certified units, also being among the highest-certified female artists overall.[114] In October, 2022, five years after her major-label debut, 
</fragment>
<fragment>

With "Girls Like You" following "I Like It" at the top of the *Billboard* Radio Songs chart, Cardi B became the first female rapper to ever replace herself at number one on that chart.[104] The single spent seven weeks atop the Hot 100, making Cardi the female rapper with the most cumulative weeks atop the chart, with eleven weeks.[105][106] It spent 33 weeks in the top 10, tying both Ed Sheeran's "Shape of You" and Post Malone and Swae Lee's "Sunflower" for the longest top 10 run in the chart's archives at the time.[107][108] In October 2018, *Invasion of Privacy* was certified double platinum by the RIAA, and the following year it was updated to triple platinum. With the thirteen tracks, she became the first female artist to have all songs from an album certified gold or higher in the US.[109]


</fragment>
</document>
msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Missy Elliott</title>
<fragment>

Elliott has widely been referred to as the "Queen of Rap" by the media. She has received numerous accolades, including four Grammy Awards.[6][7][8] Her overall discography has sold 40 million records worldwide,[9] making her the best-selling woman rapper in Nielsen Music history according to *Billboard*.[10] She was the first woman rapper to be inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame, and received the MTV VMAs Michael Jackson Video Vanguard Award for her impact on the music video landscape.[11][12] In 2020, *Billboard* ranked her at No. 5 on their list of the 100 greatest music video artists of all time.[13] In 2021, she was honored with a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. In 2023, she became the first woman rapper to be nominated and inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.[14][15][16]




## Early life[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
| * v
* t
* e
BET Award for Best Female Hip Hop Artist
 |
| --- |
| * Eve (2001)
* Missy Elliott (2002–04)
* Remy Ma (2005)
* Missy Elliott (2006, 08)
* M.I.A (2009)
* Nicki Minaj (2010–16)
* Remy Ma (2017)
* Cardi B (2018–19)
* Megan Thee Stallion (2020–22)
* Latto (2023)
 |


</fragment>
<fragment>
During the late 1990s and early 2000s, she sold more than 7.6 million copies in the United States, being a women rapper with best-selling albums in the country, followed by Lauryn Hill (seven million), Lil' Kim (four million), and Eve (four million) at the time.[51]



### 2005–2006: *The Cookbook* and *Respect M.E.*[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
*The New Yorker* stated that Elliott became the first Black female rapper to reach the mainstream in Middle America.[111] An article from *Vibe* credits Elliott's debut album *Supa Dupa Fly* for "changing the rap game for women", noting the rapper's "refusal to be pigeonholed" with her image, and instead, embraced "the complexities inherent with Black womanhood", with the author commenting that female rappers tend to be placed into one of two categories: androgyny or hyper-sexualization.[112] *The New York Times* and *The Bulletin* have called her the "Queen of the Beats".[113][114] Jem Aswad of *Variety* commented that Elliott and longtime collaborator Timbaland "reshaped the sound of hip-hop", as they made songs "out of pings and bips and bloops (both vocal and electronic) that quickly became part of the foundation of virtually all that followed."[115] Similarly, Doreen St. 
</fragment>
<fragment>
	* Shaw, Andrea Elizabeth (2006), *The Embodiment of Disobedience: Fat Black Women's Unruly Political Bodies*, Lexington Books, p. 100, ISBN 0-7391-1487-5, Missy Elliott, reigning queen of rap, releases five albums in only six years, earns two Grammys, the 2003 American Music Award, and MTV's 2003 Video of the Year.
	* "Breakdancing is Back". *BBC News*. From Run DMC vs Jason Nivens' classic New York battle, to the queen of rap - Missy Elliot.
	* "Madonna to adopt?; The Douglases' skimpy court award; Missy Elliott scraps with photographer". *San Francisco Chronicle*. November 7, 2003. Queen of rap Missy Elliott...
	* Mitchell, Claudia; Reid-Valsh, Jacqueline (2008), *Girl Culture: Studying girl culture: a reader's guide*, Greenwood Publishing Group, p. 276, ISBN 978-0-313-33908-0, Widely regarded as the queen of rap music, Missy Elliott is an icon of girl culture because of her innovative style and ability to succeed in the music industry without objectifying herself.

</fragment>
<fragment>
Elliott has been referred to as the "Queen of Rap",[102][103] the "Queen of Hip Hop",[104] and the "First Lady of Hip Hop"[105] by several media outlets. 
</fragment>
<fragment>
	* Dazed (November 9, 2021). "From Chanel to KAWS: Here's what makes Bree Runway tick". *Dazed*. Retrieved November 10, 2021. and to the queen of rap herself, Missy Elliott
	* "'I'm Better', le nouveau titre de Missy Elliott". *RTBF* (in French). Belgium. 2017. La reine du rap
	* "Missy Elliott - "I'm Better (Feat. Lamb)"". *Wonderland*. UK. February 8, 2017. queen of rap is back
	* Diss, Sam (November 13, 2015). "Can We Talk About Pharrell's Verse on Missy Elliott's "WTF (Where They From)"?". *Vice*. the unimpeachable queen of rap
	* Baker, Lindsay (November 7, 2003). "Queen of rap: Missy Elliot". *Mail & Guardian*.
104. **^** "Queen of Hip Hop"


</fragment>
</document>

msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Queen Latifah</title>
<fragment>

Often cited as one of the best female rappers,[76] Queen Latifah achieved groundbreaking success[77] in the late 1980s and early 1990s, and became what *Pitchfork* considered as the "most recognizable female rapper" of the golden era of hip hop.[78] *AllMusic* writer Steve Huey stated that Latifah was "certainly not the first female rapper, but she was the first one to become a bona fide star."[2] In the book *Notable Black American Women*, Jessie Carney Smith hailed her as "rap's first feminist" and "one of the few women to make a mark in the male-dominated field of rap music".[79] *Variety* called her "one of the major forerunners for women in modern hip-hop,"[80] and *The Guardian* referred to her as a "pioneer of female rap".[81]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Throughout her career, several media publications have referred to her as the "Queen of Rap"[50][82][83] including *New York* magazine (1990) via editor Dinitia Smith,[79] as well as "Queen of Hip Hop".[82][81][84][51] Latifah became the first solo female rapper to receive a RIAA certification for an album (*Black Reign*), a commercial breakthrough that the *AllMusic* editor considered as creating a path for "a talented crew of women rappers to make their own way onto the charts as the 90s progressed".[2] Her breakthrough also helped place New Jersey on the hip hop map.[51] In 1998, she performed in the Super Bowl XXXII halftime show, making her the first rapper to do so.[24]


</fragment>
<fragment>
75. **^** "Foxy Brown – "Na Na Be Like" – Live (2000)". Archived from the original on March 29, 2014. Retrieved May 8, 2013 – via YouTube.
76. **^** "Top 10 female rappers of all time: Did your favorite make our list?". *The Mercury News*. August 6, 2020. Retrieved August 5, 2022. \* "HHW's Top 30 Greatest Female Rap Artists of All Time, Ranked". *The Latest Hip-Hop News, Music and Media | Hip-Hop Wired*. March 25, 2021. Retrieved August 5, 2022.
77. **^** "Queen Latifah Unable To Accept Marian Anderson Award, Citing Personal Reasons; Will Be Honored In The Future – CBS Philly". October 12, 2018. Retrieved August 5, 2022.
78. **^** "Will the Mainstream Support More than One Rap Queen at a Time? A Charts Investigation". *pitchfork.com*. April 13, 2017. Retrieved August 5, 2022.
79. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Smith, Jessie Carney (1992). *Notable Black American Women*. VNR AG. ISBN 9780810391772.
80. **^** "Variety 500: Queen Latifah". *Variety*.

</fragment>
<fragment>

*Vibe* magazine has noted her as the first female rapper to cross over into TV & film,[88] as an artist that "broke barriers and set standards" for Black women in music to follow, and cited her as the "First Lady of Hip-Hop".[22] For her performance as Matron "Mama" Morton in *Chicago*, Latifah earned a nomination for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress, becoming the first woman in hip hop to earn an Oscar nomination.[89]



### Cultural impact[edit]


Queen Latifah has been cited as an influence on R&B, soul, and hip-hop artists, such as Eve,[90] Da Brat,[91] Lil' Kim,[92] Fugees,[93] Jill Scott,[94] Lauryn Hill,[95] Missy Elliott,[96] Remy Ma,[97] Ivy Queen,[98] Foxy Brown,[99] Ms. Dynamite,[100] Naughty by Nature,[101] Rapsody,[102] Megan Thee Stallion,[103] as well as actors Michael K. Williams,[104] Keke Palmer,[105] Vin Diesel,[106] and author Jason Reynolds.[107]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Early in her career, Queen Latifah's lyrics were described as woman-centered and Afrocentric. The rapper often used Afrocentric attires during public appearances and music videos, looks that became her trademark.[51] In 1990, *The New York Times*' Michelle Wallace described her art as "politically sophisticated", which "seems worlds apart from the adolescent, buffoonish sex orientation of most rap."[52] For *AllMusic*, her "strong, intelligent, no-nonsense" persona made her "arguably the first MC who could properly be described as feminist".[2] Queen Latifah did not identify as a feminist at the time, and expressed that her music was not exclusive for the female audience.[53] On the topic, author Tricia Rose wrote that Black female rappers likely did not identify with feminism during that time because it was perceived as a movement that focused primarily on white women's issues.[54]



## Products and endorsements[edit]


</fragment>
</document>
msg.name: search

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Queen Latifah</title>
<fragment>

Often cited as one of the best female rappers,[76] Queen Latifah achieved groundbreaking success[77] in the late 1980s and early 1990s, and became what *Pitchfork* considered as the "most recognizable female rapper" of the golden era of hip hop.[78] *AllMusic* writer Steve Huey stated that Latifah was "certainly not the first female rapper, but she was the first one to become a bona fide star."[2] In the book *Notable Black American Women*, Jessie Carney Smith hailed her as "rap's first feminist" and "one of the few women to make a mark in the male-dominated field of rap music".[79] *Variety* called her "one of the major forerunners for women in modern hip-hop,"[80] and *The Guardian* referred to her as a "pioneer of female rap".[81]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Throughout her career, several media publications have referred to her as the "Queen of Rap"[50][82][83] including *New York* magazine (1990) via editor Dinitia Smith,[79] as well as "Queen of Hip Hop".[82][81][84][51] Latifah became the first solo female rapper to receive a RIAA certification for an album (*Black Reign*), a commercial breakthrough that the *AllMusic* editor considered as creating a path for "a talented crew of women rappers to make their own way onto the charts as the 90s progressed".[2] Her breakthrough also helped place New Jersey on the hip hop map.[51] In 1998, she performed in the Super Bowl XXXII halftime show, making her the first rapper to do so.[24]


</fragment>
<fragment>
75. **^** "Foxy Brown – "Na Na Be Like" – Live (2000)". Archived from the original on March 29, 2014. Retrieved May 8, 2013 – via YouTube.
76. **^** "Top 10 female rappers of all time: Did your favorite make our list?". *The Mercury News*. August 6, 2020. Retrieved August 5, 2022. \* "HHW's Top 30 Greatest Female Rap Artists of All Time, Ranked". *The Latest Hip-Hop News, Music and Media | Hip-Hop Wired*. March 25, 2021. Retrieved August 5, 2022.

80. **^** "Variety 500: Queen Latifah". *Variety*.

</fragment>
<fragment>

*Vibe* magazine has noted her as the first female rapper to cross over into TV & film,[88] as an artist that "broke barriers and set standards" for Black women in music to follow, and cited her as the "First Lady of Hip-Hop".[22] For her performance as Matron "Mama" Morton in *Chicago*, Latifah earned a nomination for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress, becoming the first woman in hip hop to earn an Oscar nomination.[89]

Queen Latifah has been cited as an influence on R&B, soul, and hip-hop artists, such as Eve,[90] Da Brat,[91] Lil' Kim,[92] Fugees,[93] Jill Scott,[94] Lauryn Hill,[95] Missy Elliott,[96] Remy Ma,[97] Ivy Queen,[98] Foxy Brown,[99] Ms. Dynamite,[100] Naughty by Nature,[101] Rapsody,[102] Megan Thee Stallion,[103] as well as actors Michael K. Williams,[104] Keke Palmer,[105] Vin Diesel,[106] and author Jason Reynolds.[107]


</fragment>
<fragment>

Early in her career, Queen Latifah's lyrics were described as woman-centered and Afrocentric. The rapper often used Afrocentric attires during public appearances and music videos, looks that became her trademark.[51] In 1990, *The New York Times*' Michelle Wallace described her art as "politically sophisticated", which "seems worlds apart from the adolescent, buffoonish sex orientation of most rap."[52] For *AllMusic*, her "strong, intelligent, no-nonsense" persona made her "arguably the first MC who could properly be described as feminist".[2] Queen Latifah did not identify as a feminist at the time, and expressed that her music was not exclusive for the female audience.[53] On the topic, author Tricia Rose wrote that Black female rappers likely did not identify with feminism during that time because it was perceived as a movement that focused primarily on white women's issues.[54]

msg.content:
<document>
<title>Lauryn Hill</title>
<fragment>
295. **^** Rob, D. J. (April 15, 2018). "Here's The Short List of Female Rappers To Top The Billboard Album Chart …And The LONG List Of Those Who Haven't". *Djrobblog.com*. Archived from the original on January 21, 2021. Retrieved March 9, 2021.
296. **^** "Cardi B Becomes Fifth Female Rapper to Hit No. 1 on Billboard 200 Albums Chart". *Billboard*. Retrieved March 9, 2021.
297. **^** "5 Reasons Lauryn Hill's Influence On Music Is Incomparable". *HuffPost*. August 27, 2015. Archived from the original on October 20, 2021. Retrieved October 20, 2021.
298. **^** "'Work' Week: Rihanna Tops Hot 100 for Seventh Week, Fifth Harmony Earns First Top 10 Hit". *Billboard*. Retrieved March 6, 2021.
299. **^** "1999 GRAMMY AWARDS // Lauryn Hill wins best album, breaks female artist record". *Tampa Bay Times*. Archived from the original on February 6, 2022. Retrieved February 6, 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>
180. **^** Robby Seabrook III (August 22, 2022). "These Are the Best Singing Rappers Who Make You Forget They Rap". *XXL Mag*. Archived from the original on January 1, 2023. Retrieved January 1, 2023.
181. **^** "Billboard – Google Books". May 5, 2022. Archived from the original on May 5, 2022. Retrieved May 5, 2022.
182. **^** "13 Lyrics That Prove Nicki Minaj Is One of the Greatest Rappers of All Time". *Mic*. April 28, 2015. Archived from the original on February 3, 2022. Retrieved February 5, 2022.
183. **^** "The Next Generation of Lauryn Hill: 16 Artists on Their Favorite 'Miseducation' Songs". *Billboard*. Retrieved October 20, 2020.
184. **^** "'All hail the queens': A look back at the legacy of women in hip-hop – ABC News". *ABC News*. October 19, 2021. Archived from the original on October 19, 2021. Retrieved October 20, 2021.
185. **^** "Billboard – Google Books". May 5, 2022. Archived from the original on May 5, 2022. Retrieved May 5, 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>
**Lauryn Noelle Hill** (born May 26, 1975) is an American rapper, singer, songwriter, and record producer. She is regarded as one of the greatest rappers of all time,[2] as well as one of the most influential musicians of her generation. Hill is credited for breaking barriers for female rappers, popularizing melodic rap, redefining hip hop, and helping neo soul reach mainstream popularity. In addition to being named one of the 50 Great Voices by NPR, Hill was listed as one of the 200 Greatest Singers of All Time by *Rolling Stone*. In 2015, she was ranked as the greatest woman rapper by *Billboard*. Her accolades include eight Grammy Awards, the most for a female rapper to this day.


</fragment>
<fragment>
![](image)Hill performing in 2019
Hill is widely considered[156] to be one of the greatest rappers of all time,[2] and has often been called the greatest female rapper.[157] *The New York Times* once referred to Hill as "the most popular woman in hip-hop".[158] Rapper Kool Moe Dee gave Hill the highest score of any rapper on his rap 'Report Cards' list from the book, *Ego Trip's Book of Rap Lists.*[159] Furthermore, Beyoncé once stated that she is "one of the best hip-hop rappers ever".[160] In 1998, *Time* declared her as the "Queen of Hip Hop";[161] while Academy of Achievement,[162] *The Boston Globe*,[163] and *Billboard*,[164] among others,[165] have also crowned her with the same title. In 2015, *Billboard* ranked Hill as the seventh greatest rapper of all time on their "10 Best Rappers of All Time" list, with her being the only woman on the list.[166][167] In the peak of her career, Hill had earned over $25 million for her work.[168]


</fragment>
<fragment>

In 1999, *Billboard* considered Hill's success to be a breakthrough for female rappers, which resulted in a brief increase of female rappers in the music industry at the time, that the publication dubbed 'The Lauryn Hill Effect'. Author Nelson George noted, "the presence of women is increasing"; while Missy Elliott also added that "Latifah opened the door for doing TV, and she might have opened it for Brandy. Now, it's open for everybody. This is just the beginning".[185] That same year, a public survey was conducted by MTV, which directly impacted its programming. In the survey, she was ranked the most respected solo artist, and placed among the acts that participants thought best defined their generation; with former Viacom executive Todd Cunningham referring to Hill as a "massive phenomenon".[186] Music journalist Danyel Smith credited Hill with reviving the hip hop genre, following the murders of The Notorious B.I.G. and Tupac Shakur.[187]



### Influence on other artists[edit]


</fragment>
</document>

msg.content:
Here is information about the origins of some of the best-selling female rappers:

1. **Nicki Minaj**:
   - **Origin**: Nicki Minaj was born in Saint James, Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago, and raised in Queens, New York City, USA.

2. **Cardi B**:
   - **Origin**: Cardi B was born and raised in The Bronx, New York City, USA.

3. **Missy Elliott**:
   - **Origin**: Missy Elliott was born in Portsmouth, Virginia, USA.

4. **Queen Latifah**:
   - **Origin**: Queen Latifah was born in Newark, New Jersey, USA.

5. **Lauryn Hill**:
   - **Origin**: Lauryn Hill was born in East Orange, New Jersey, USA.
